comments.text: Next, we review an equivalent definition of the Euler class of smooth vector bundles over smooth manifolds. Let $\xi: E\to M$ be an orientable smooth vector bundle over an orientable closed connected smooth manifold $M$, $\sigma_{0}: M\to E$ the zero section so that we view $M$ as a submanifold of $E$, and $\sigma:M\to E$ a generic smooth section in the sense that $\sigma_{0}$ and $\sigma$ meet transversally. Denote $\mathrm{rank}(\xi)$=k and $\mathrm{dim}(M)=n$.Then the zero locus of $\sigma$, denoted by $Z(\sigma)$, is an orientable submanifold of $M$ (with a canonical orientation). The embedding $Z(\sigma)\to M$ pushes forward the fundamental class of $M$ to a homology class $[Z(\sigma)]\in H_{n-k}(M)$. Now apply Poincare duality of $M$ to this class, and the resulting cohomology class $PD([Z(\sigma)])=e(\xi)\in H^{k}(M;\mathbb{Z})$ is exactly the Euler class of $\xi$.

Now let us come to the problem. Let us assume that $n\geqslant 1$ so that $S^{n+1}$ is simply connected and thus all vector bundles over $S^{n+1}$ is orientable. Also here we may assume that all vector bundles are smooth as clutching functions can be made smooth (this can be seen later). For a $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}-$bundle over $S^{n+1}$, the generic smooth section intersets the zero section at finite points by dimension reason, hence to compute the Euler class is equivalent to compute the intersecting number $\sigma_{0}\cdot\sigma$. Let $\alpha\in\pi_{n}(O(n+1))$ be a homotopy class, which can be always represented by a smooth map using smooth approximation, $\tilde{\alpha}:S^{n}\times\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\to S^{n}\times\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ the smooth clutching map, and $\eta=\eta_{\alpha}$ the resulting vector bundle (saying $E$ the total space), which is thus smooth. Take the trivializations $h_{\pm}:E\_{D^{n+1}_{\pm}}\to D^{n+1}_{\pm}\times\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. Using $h_{+}$, we can construct a nowhere-zero section $\sigma_{1}:D^{n+1}_{+}\to E\_{D^{n+1}_{\pm}}$ of $\eta|_{D^{n+1}_{+}}$ so that $h_{+}\sigma_{1}(x)=(x,v)$ for some unit vector $v\in\mathbb{R^{n}}$. The bundle form of Tietze extension theorem will imply that we can extend $\sigma_{1}$ to a section $\sigma_{2}$ on the whole base space $S^{n+1}$. Then homotope $\sigma_{2}$ to a smooth generic section $\sigma$ such that $\sigma|_{D^{n+1}_{+}}=\sigma_{1}|_{D^{n+1}_{+}}$ as $\sigma_{1}}$ is already smooth on the closed subset $D^{n+1}_{+}$. Then $\sigma$ can vanish only on the lower open hemisphere, and thus  to compute the intersection number $\sigma\cdot\sigma_{0}=\sigma|_{D^{n+1}_{-}}\cdot\sigma_{0}|_{D^{n+1}_{-}}$, we only need to focus on the lower hemisphere.

Transport the intersection number via trivialization $h_{-}$, and $\sigma_{-}:=\sigma|_{D^{n+1}_{-}}$ is now a vector field on $D^{n+1}$, and $\mathrm{p}_{2}\circ h_{-}\circ\sigma_{-}$ is just a smooth map $V:D^{n+1}_{-} to\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ that is nowhere vanishing on the boundary. Recall that $\sigma$ is defined by extending the  nowhere-zero section $\sigma_{1}$ that corresponds to the map $D^{n+1}\to D^{n+1}\times \mathbb{R}^{n+1},x\mapsto (x,v),v\in S^{n}$. Restrict to the boundary sphere, transport this map via clutching function $\tilde{\alpha}$, and we see that $w:=V|_{S^{n}}$ takes the form $x\mapsto (x,v)\mapsto (x,\alpha(x)v)\mapsto \alpha(x)v$. As $\sigma$ is generic, v has only isolated nondegenerate zeros. Now we will use a lemma by Hopf (cf. J. Milnor, Topology from Differential Viewpoint): by definition, $\mathrm{ind}(V)=sigma|_{D^{n+1}_{-}}\cdot\sigma_{0}|_{D^{n+1}_{-}}=\sigma\cdot\sigma_{0}$, and by Hopf's lemma, $\mathrm{ind}(V)=\mathrm{deg}(\hat{w})$, where $\hat{w}:S^{n}\to S^{n}$ is the unit normalization of $w$ and is just $w$ itself as $v$ has length $1$ and $\alpha$ takes value in $O(n+1}$. Since $w(x)=\alpha(x)v$, and $v$ is a constant vector, we see that $w$ is the pushforward of the map $\alpha$ along the bundle projection $p:O(n+1}\to S^{n}$. Now it is sufficient to draw the desired 
conclusion.
#令人不适

data.text:
#57479
First let us make it clear how $\pi_{n}(O(n+1))$ is identified to the set of isomorphism classes of vector bundles over $S^{n+1}$ of rank $n+1$. Note $S^{n+1}=D^{n+1}_{+}\cup D^{n+1}_{-}$ is obtained by gluing two contractible spaces, namely the upper and lower semispheres along their boundary $n-$sphere. Then clutching construction of vector bundles tells us that, each map $\alpha: S^{n}\to O(n+1)$ induces a map $\tilde{\alpha}: S^{n}\times\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\to S^{n}\times\mathbb{R}^{n+1}, (x,v)\mapsto (x,\alpha(x)v)$; then $\eta_{\alpha}:=D^{n+1}\times\mathbf{R}^{n+1}\cup_{\tilde{\alpha}}D^{n+1}\times\mathbf{R}^{n+1}$ gives a vector bundle, and homotopy $\alpha's$ give isomorphic vector bundle. Moreover, the converse of the process is also true, namely given an $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}-$bundle over $S^{n+1}$, its restriction to upper and lower hemispheres are trivial bundles, and it gives rise to a clutching map $S^{n}\times\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\to S^{n}\times\mathbb{R}^{n+1}, (x,v)\mapsto (x,\beta(x)v)$ for some continuous map $\beta: S^{n}\to GL(n+1,\mathbb{R})$, and thus a map $\beta: S^{n}\to O(n+1)$ as $GL(n+1,\mathbb{R})$ deformation retracts onto $O(n+1)$ (or a priori equip the bundle with an Euclidean metric). And the assignment from a bundle to a map passes to the assignment from an equivalent class of bundles to a homotopy class.

待人不坦诚，对人不尊敬，感觉经常利用别人的价值为自己谋便利
感觉现在自己的种种不自信都是从那时候来的，现在所遇到的种种问题当时的经历也没有丝毫的用处，甚至偶而觉得自己面目可憎，感叹自己何时变成一个价值观如此扭曲之人了
现在越想越感觉是受了他们的影响
生活总是这样，你以为失去的，可能在来的路上；你以为拥有的，可能在去的途中。
